awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Applying a Criminological Framework to Understand Adaptive Adversarial Decision-Making Processes in Critical Infrastructure Cyberattacks
awd_abstract_narration:
Infrastructure systems (such as power, water and banking) have experienced a surge in cyberattacks over the past decade. These attacks are becoming more sophisticated and resilient, suggesting that the perpetrators are intelligent, determined and dynamic. Unfortunately, current cyberdefense measures are reactive and frequently ineffective. Defenders need to move to a proactive approach, which will require an understanding of the human characteristics and behaviors of the people behind these cyberattacks. At present, this absence of the human element in existing cyberattack analysis is a fundamental weakness in our infrastructure protection. This project will integrate observations from live cybersecurity exercises, interviews with infrastructure protection experts, and logs from real-time cyberattacks to understand adaptive adversarial processes. This research will offer a new understanding to the protection of digital infrastructure by bringing together a diverse set of multidisciplinary academics and national and international infrastructure cybersecurity experts.

This project will investigate the adaptive and evolving adversarial decision-making (ADM) process in critical infrastructure cyberattacks. Specifically, this project will apply a criminological perspective to achieve five research objectives: (1) Investigate adversary-defender interaction and identify adversarial attack paths, (2) Understand adversarial adaptability when attack paths are disrupted, (3) Investigate the importance and characteristics of the various stages in attack paths, (4) Identify which factors impact ADM at each stage of the attack path, and (5) Improve the transparency, consistency and validation of adversarial attack paths. The Rational Choice Perspective criminological theoretical framework will be exploited to comprehend how adversaries make decisions on target selection, exploit criminal environments, plan, design, and execute attacks, and manage preventative and reactive measures. Three methods will be triangulated to examine ADM: (i) interviews with infrastructure cybersecurity experts to identify attack paths and factors impacting ADM, (ii) observations of attacker-defender (red team-blue team) cybersecurity exercises to examine real-time and adaptive decision-making processes, and (iii) logs from real-time cyberattacks. Each of these datasets will yield unique perspectives on ADM processes and will be combined to better capture the human element in cyberattacks.

por.por_cntn:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT

1. Adversarial behaviors

Three main sets of factors impact adversarial decision-making. (i) Adversarial-specific: time, effort, money, reliability, skills, knowledge, and research and development; (ii) Defender-specific: response time; response type; and (iii) System-specific: System architecture; prevention measures; intrusion-detection.

A rational model of adversarial decision-making involves four stages: (i) orientation, where the group defines the problem and discusses any steps that could be taken to solve the problem, (ii) discussion, where the group gathers and processes information relevant to the decision, (iii) decision-making, where the group chooses a solution via a variety of mechanisms, such as averaging individual inputs, voting, and consensus, and (iv) implementation, where the group implements the decision and then evaluates it.

2. Group dynamics and divisions of labor

Observed group dynamics suggested minimal hierarchy with equally distributed divisions of labor amongst sub-groups that comprised members with closely aligned skill sets. Groups had predetermined team leaders or co-leaders, whose roles varied among the teams, but whose responsibilities primarily included coordinating and distributing work to other team members, prioritizing individual tasks, keeping group members focused, and overseeing documentation. Some groups had leaders who assigned tasks to team members, while other groups had the freedom to choose their own jobs and responsibilities. Each member?s independent task depended on their skillset, whether it was chosen by them or assigned to them. Skill sets ranged from technical capabilities to business and organizational skills, which were required for the various components of the cyberattack. Sub-group membership, while initially based on common or complementary skill sets, was transient and shifting. Adversarial members often moved from one sub-group to another depending on where their skills or assistance were needed. During disruptions, there was a clear change between sub-group orientation; a change in team dynamics occurred so that the team would focus more on certain attack stages.

3. Disruptions to cyberattacks and adversarial adaptations

Typically, three types of disruptions occurred during cyberattacks: defender responses, limited adversarial knowledge, and adversarial errors. Each of these disruptions limited how adversaries could progress through the attack process. Most defender disruptions were cutting adversarial access, but on occasion there was the use of decoys to mislead adversaries. Limited adversarial knowledge occurred when adversaries did not know specific tools, how to manage unknown vulnerabilities, and how to proceed when they could not make further progress on their specific tasks. Finally, adversarial team members made errors such as shutting down their own or team members' access points into the targeted systems.

Five main adversarial responses or adaptations when they experienced roadblocks during their attacks included (i) fulfilling as many objectives as possible with their existing/active attack paths; (ii) trying other tasks to maintain operations; (iii) included regaining access, (iv) gaining administrative access and greater privileges, and (v) pivoting from failed attempts or partially successful tactics.

4. Attack intrusion chains

The research suggests that (i) cyberattack stages do not occur in a clear sequence as indicated by most intrusion chain models, which suggests that adversaries may exhibit complex back and forth movement when they face disruptions, (ii) after disruptions, adversaries may focus on multiple stages simultaneously, further suggesting that stages do not occur in sequence, but rather in parallel, and (iii) most of adaptations occurred with a specific intrusion stage (build/acquire tools).

After disruptions adversaries focused on multiple intrusion chain stages at either the same time (concurrent) or with a slight temporal lead (a few minutes apart), suggesting that stages occur in parallel rather than in sequence.

5. Methodological advances in studying unfolding cyberattacks

This research went beyond traditional ways of qualitatively studying cyberattacks (observations, interviews, and focus groups), but also intersected technical methodologies, such as (i) time series analysis to further explore adversarial decision-making and adaptation along intrusion chains, (ii) machine learning to predict adversarial behavior, (iii) social network analysis, graph theory, and agent based modeling to understand adversarial movement across intrusion chains and the relationship between skillsets and movement. Collectively, these methods allowed the social and technical sciences to align their data analytical techniques to explore adversarial behavior. These also serve as proof of concepts in demonstrating how social and technical data analyses can work together.

BROADER IMPACT

Given the reactive nature of cybersecurity, this research offered a social science lens to explore cyberadvesaries. Understanding how adversaries move along cyberattack chains, how they respond to different types of disruptions, how they work in groups and carry out divisions of labor, can all help anticipate adversarial behaviors. These ideas can help shift reactive cybersecurity efforts to more proactive cybersecurity initiatives. Furthermore, the research demonstrates how technical and social science analytic methods can be combined and potentially used to inform more human (adversarial) centric defense measures. The research also resulted in the creation of a free critical infrastructure ransomware incident dataset and several course projects that can be used by the wider community.
